elements.title: Myth-First Content Hierarchy on Landing
elements.problem: The discovery page must convince a skeptical stranger to believe in the platform's imagined reality before asking for any participation. Current information hierarchy may lead with functional UI (search bars, filters, sign-up prompts) rather than with the evidence that the collective fiction is real — active listings, social proof, neighborhood context. This is equivalent to asking someone to believe in a company's existence before showing them any product.
elements.solution: Structure the discovery page with a three-tier content hierarchy: (1) Hero evidence — real listings, real photos, real neighborhoods that prove the platform is active and alive; (2) Social proof — aggregate trust signals (number of active leases, verified reviews count, guest testimonials) that demonstrate other strangers already believe in this fiction; (3) Action invitation — search bar, filters, and progressive refinement offered only after value has been demonstrated.

evidence.quote: Large numbers of strangers can cooperate successfully by believing in common myths. Any large-scale human cooperation — whether a modern state, a medieval church, an ancient city or an archaic tribe — is rooted in common myths that exist only in people's collective imagination.
evidence.insight: The landing page must function as the platform's foundational myth-telling moment — showing evidence of the collective fiction's reality (active users, real spaces) before asking the stranger to participate.

evidence.quote: Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them. Show something useful first. Offer to refine after.
evidence.insight: Information architecture must lead with value (the myth's evidence) and trail with asks (participation demands). Reversing this order breaks the stranger's willingness to engage.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Evidence of the collective fiction's reality precedes any request for participation. Real listings > social proof > action invitations. The guest should feel 'other people believe in this' before being asked to join.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Progressive disclosure across three tiers: Tier 1 shows proof of life (listings, photos, activity); Tier 2 reveals social validation (reviews, trust counts); Tier 3 invites action (search, filter, sign up). Each tier is accessible without completing the previous, but the visual weight descends.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 3 competing information categories visible in the first viewport. No more than 1 call-to-action visible before the guest has scrolled past at least one evidence section. Zero data-entry fields in the hero area.

elements.title: Gossip-Rich Listing Card Information Layers
elements.problem: Listing cards currently display a flat information hierarchy that treats all data points equally. The guest scanning a search grid is performing rapid stranger-assessment — they need gossip-relevant information (who is this host? is this space real? is it available?) organized in a priority order that matches their evolutionary scanning instinct. A flat card forces the guest to do the information-prioritization work themselves, slowing the gossip process.
elements.solution: Structure listing card information in three explicit layers: (1) Glance layer (always visible) — primary photo, price, neighborhood name, and one trust signal (rating or 'verified'); (2) Scan layer (visible on hover or tap) — photo count indicator, availability window, host response time, quick save action; (3) Deep layer (accessible via card expansion or click-through) — full description preview, amenity highlights, distance to transit. Each layer adds gossip bandwidth without overwhelming the initial scan.

evidence.quote: Reliable information about who could be trusted meant that small bands could expand into larger bands, and Sapiens could develop tighter and more sophisticated types of cooperation.
evidence.insight: The listing card's information architecture must optimize for trust-assessment speed. Each data layer is a gossip channel — the more efficiently it conveys who is trustworthy, the faster the guest can expand their cooperation circle to include this host.

evidence.quote: The current card works but it's leaving engagement on the table. Richer hover states, image counters, availability indicators, neighborhood labels, and quick actions — all without leaving the search grid.
evidence.insight: The card needs more gossip layers, not more data. The distinction matters: layers are progressive, discoverable, and scoped. Data dumped flat is noise.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Gossip-relevant information (trust, availability, responsiveness) outranks descriptive information (amenities, square footage). The guest's first question is 'Can I trust this stranger?' not 'How big is the kitchen?'
elements.disclosure_pattern: Three-layer progressive reveal: Glance (always visible, 4 data points max) → Scan (hover/tap, 4-5 additional signals) → Deep (click-through to listing detail). Each layer answers a higher-fidelity trust question.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Glance layer: maximum 4 data points (photo, price, location, one trust signal). Scan layer: maximum 5 additional data points. No text blocks longer than 8 words on any layer. Card height does not exceed 1.5x its width.

elements.title: Trust-Evidence Display on Listing Detail
elements.problem: On the listing detail page, the guest transitions from gossip-level scanning to intimate assessment of a single stranger. Harari shows that beyond Dunbar's number, cooperation requires fictional trust entities (reviews, badges, credentials). If these are buried below the fold, behind tabs, or presented without clear hierarchy, the guest cannot efficiently bridge the trust gap. The listing detail must present the strongest trust evidence first — another user's word — before the platform's own claims.
elements.solution: Structure the listing detail page with trust-first information architecture: (1) Top section — photo gallery, price summary, and host identity block (name, photo, verification status, response rate); (2) Trust section (above the fold) — review summary (count, average, most recent quote), verification badges, host tenure on platform; (3) Listing details — space description, amenities, rules, availability calendar; (4) Action section — proposal CTA, message CTA, always visible as sticky element.

evidence.quote: Trade cannot exist without trust, and it is very difficult to trust strangers. The global trade network of today is based on our trust in such fictional entities as the dollar, the Federal Reserve Bank, and the totemic trademarks of corporations.
evidence.insight: The listing detail page is where the guest makes the trade-trust decision. The information architecture must present the fictional trust entities (reviews, verification, host history) with the same prominence that a bank presents its credentials — because they serve the same function.

evidence.quote: A skeptical guest who sees verified reviews, ID checks, and real host history doesn't need the platform to convince them — another user already did.
evidence.insight: Peer evidence outranks platform assertion in the information hierarchy. Reviews from past guests are the strongest trust signal and must appear before the platform's own verification claims.

evidence.quote: Even if a user loves what they see on the card, they'll still open the listing before committing — to check host reviews, credibility, full photos. The jump from card to proposal skips steps people naturally need.
evidence.insight: The listing detail page is a mandatory trust-evaluation step. Its information architecture must be optimized for this specific intent: assessing whether this specific stranger is trustworthy enough to cooperate with.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Peer trust evidence (reviews, ratings) outranks platform trust claims (verification badges) which outrank listing descriptors (amenities, rules). The hierarchy follows the principle: 'A stranger who has cooperated with this host is more credible than the platform that hosts them.'
elements.disclosure_pattern: Trust-first progressive disclosure: host identity and review summary visible in first viewport; full review list expandable in-place; listing details follow below; action buttons persist as sticky elements. No tab-switching required to see trust + details together.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: First viewport contains maximum 3 information zones (photos, host identity + trust, price summary). Review summary is a single scannable line (e.g., '4.8 from 12 verified reviews') with one-tap expansion to full list. No interstitial clicks between trust evaluation and action.

elements.title: Ritual-Clarity Proposal Form Structure
elements.problem: The proposal form is the platform's incorporation ritual — the moment dates, prices, and terms become an intersubjective reality shared between two strangers. If the form's information architecture is unclear (ambiguous fields, hidden costs, confusing term structures), the ritual fails and the shared fiction does not crystallize. Price transparency at every decision point is critical because the guest is about to convert a negotiable fiction into a binding one.
elements.solution: Structure the proposal form as a clear, linear ritual with three visible sections: (1) What you're proposing — pre-populated listing name, dates, schedule, with clear edit affordances; (2) What it costs — itemized price breakdown visible at all times, no hidden fees, running total updates live as terms change; (3) Confirm and submit — a distinct confirmation moment with a summary of all terms, explicit 'Submit Proposal' action that feels deliberate, not accidental.

evidence.quote: If a certified lawyer followed all the proper liturgy and rituals, wrote all the required spells and oaths on a wonderfully decorated piece of paper, and affixed his ornate signature to the bottom of the document, then hocus pocus — a new company was incorporated.
evidence.insight: The proposal form must follow 'proper liturgy' — clear steps, visible terms, a ceremonial confirmation — so that the intersubjective fiction (the proposed lease) feels real and binding to both parties.

evidence.quote: A well-structured proposal — clear dates, schedule, pricing, intent — activates the host to respond. A vague or incomplete one creates friction. Stories that push toward more structured, pre-populated proposal forms aren't just about UX, they're about making the cross-activation moment as clean as possible.
evidence.insight: Form structure directly determines cross-activation success: a clear proposal creates a strong shared fiction, while an ambiguous one leaves both parties unsure what they have agreed to imagine together.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Terms before cost before commitment. The guest must understand what they are proposing, then what it costs, then confirm. Price transparency is not a feature — it is a structural requirement for the ritual to succeed.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Linear three-section form: Section 1 (pre-populated terms, editable) → Section 2 (live price breakdown, always visible) → Section 3 (summary + confirm). No accordion panels, no hidden sections. All information visible by scrolling, never by switching views.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 6 editable fields across the entire form. Price summary updates in real-time as fields change. Confirmation section fits in a single viewport and contains no new information — only a summary of what was entered above.

elements.title: Fiction-Reality Alignment at Move-In
elements.problem: Move-in is the collision between the guest's imagined reality (the listing, the reviews, the lease agreement) and the objective reality of the physical space. If the information the guest receives during move-in (House Manual, check-in procedures, contact details) is disorganized, incomplete, or inaccessible, the fiction-reality gap widens and trust collapses. The guest needs a clear, codified reference — the platform's equivalent of Harari's 'law books' — to navigate cooperation with a stranger in an intimate shared space.
elements.solution: Structure move-in information as a single-access House Manual with four clearly labeled sections: (1) Arrival — check-in procedure, key/access instructions, host contact for day-of issues; (2) House Rules — the codified cooperation norms both parties agreed to; (3) Space Guide — room assignments, appliance instructions, wifi, parking; (4) Neighborhood — transit, groceries, emergency contacts. The manual is available from the moment the lease is accepted, not just on move-in day, so the guest can prepare mentally for the fiction-reality transition.

evidence.quote: Below this threshold, communities, businesses, social networks and military units can maintain themselves based mainly on intimate acquaintance and rumour-mongering. There is no need for formal ranks, titles and law books to keep order.
evidence.insight: Beyond intimate acquaintance, cooperation requires codified rules — 'law books' — to maintain order. The House Manual is the lease's law book: it converts implicit expectations into explicit, shared norms that two strangers can follow without intimate knowledge of each other.

evidence.quote: Even if a user loves what they see on the card, they'll still open the listing before committing — to check host reviews, credibility, full photos.
evidence.insight: The guest's instinct to verify before committing extends beyond proposal — at move-in, they are verifying the physical reality against the listing fiction. The House Manual bridges this gap by providing authoritative, pre-agreed information that reduces uncertainty.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Immediate needs before orientation before reference. Arrival instructions (what do I do right now?) outrank house rules (how do we coexist?) which outrank neighborhood context (what's nearby?). The hierarchy follows the guest's temporal urgency on move-in day.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Single-document, four-section structure accessible from lease dashboard. Section 1 (Arrival) is expanded by default on move-in day; Sections 2-4 are collapsed but scannable by header. The manual is available pre-move-in for early review, with a notification nudge 24 hours before check-in.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Each section contains maximum 5 information items. Check-in procedure is maximum 4 numbered steps. House rules are presented as a scannable bullet list, not prose paragraphs. Total manual length should not exceed 2 screens of scrolling.
